channel.title: Why do banks use Java?
channel.description: I see that almost every bank I went to, and when I looked at the computer screens, they use Java software. Why do they use Java and not C++ or C?

item.title: Why do banks use Java?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

The Visual C++ compiler does not follow the GNU compiler standard, the parameters and commands are quite different. rc requires lower case /i for command line include paths, the inverse of cl, which is poor design in my opinion. The makefile syntax is a little different from GNU make, also quotes are used extensively, for example, in declarations.

Looks to me like hes saying “VC++ should accept the exact same command line arguments, makefiles and switches as the GNU compilers, because the GNU Compiler Collection totally pwns basez, dudez.”

Read full topic

item.title: Why do banks use Java?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Maybe GNU should become the standards organization for the whole world, but that is a different debate.

I assumed what they meant by not following standards is not following the C++ language standards, perhaps I was wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Why do banks use Java?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:14, topic:73953”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=108591.msg1109206#msg1109206 date=1175965596]

The Visual C++ compiler does not follow the GNU compiler standard

That just makes me wonder why they expect it to?
[/quote]

Because C++ should be a standard language. If I write it on one computer I want to be able to compile it on any computer, since VC++ doesn’t provide a compiler for anything but windows, GCC/G++ is the way to go.[/quote]

The C++ language DOES have standards, and both G++ and VC++ comply with them (for the most part, there are a few quirks, but nothing 90% of people will notice in their lifetime). What I was asking is why a Microsoft compiler should follow “GNU Compiler Standards” (whatever that means). When did the GNU suddenly become the standards organisation for the whole world?

EDIT: He seems largely to be talking about compiler switches and even makefiles, which are nothing to do with language standards at all, really. C++ isn’t Java, and while the code can quite easily be write-once, compile-almost-anywhere, I would assume that anyone maintaining a project of a size where this becomes a problem would be familiar with his target compilers anyway.

(/rant :P)

Read full topic

item.title: Why do banks use Java?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

[quote] The Visual C++ compiler does not follow the GNU compiler standard

That just makes me wonder why they expect it to?[/quote]

Because C++ should be a standard language. If I write it on one computer I want to be able to compile it on any computer, since VC++ doesn’t provide a compiler for anything but windows, GCC/G++ is the way to go.

Read full topic

item.title: Why do banks use Java?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I am far from an expert on the subject, but I have heard that the compilers are slightly different. Here is the only article I could find on it though:

Consideration of the Visual C++ compiler implementation

There was quite a bit of hocus-pocus surrounding the command line arguments and other functionality. This is also a problem with GCC to a certain extent. However, how could anyone be expected to understand the difference between _DEBUG and NDEBUG? (The former is with debugging symbols and the latter without.) The Visual C++ compiler does not follow the GNU compiler standard, the parameters and commands are quite different. rc requires lower case /i for command line include paths, the inverse of cl, which is poor design in my opinion. The makefile syntax is a little different from GNU make, also quotes are used extensively, for example, in declarations. Compared to GNU make, nmake is limited in functionality: often previously compiled code was recompiled each time nmake was executed. Furthermore, the pre-generated iainlib.mak was not as structured as Makefiles output from GNU automake. Often there was more than one definition of each program that was executed by the makefile.

RSC_PROJ was defined containing the flags for rc, but were they never used, the same arguments were passed on the command line each time! Also everything was defined twice, for release and debug. Perhaps it would have been more sensible just to add /ZI to the CPP_PROJ flags MS? (This is all that is different between the two, essentially.)

Inexplicably, it was impossible for Visual Studio to add files to the project with lower case filenames . So, I had to edit the dsp file and replace all upper case filenames and directory names with lower case.

http://codingstyle.com/articles/using-ms-vcpp-with-gnu-wine.html

Certainly, and obviously the GUI creation features of Visual C++ would be platform specific, so since GCC provides a compiler for windows as well, why not just use it?

Read full topic

item.title: Why do banks use Java?
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

I’m adding very little to what has already been said. Most of the above answers the question sufficiently. Banks are also notoriously stingy. Java has a very fast time to market for applications and upgrades. It is relatively simple to maintain. It’s got a huge following. (India and China both have hundreds upon thousands of ‘coder sweat shops’ that do nothing but contract java coding). And really, to be honest, Java is easy to a fault. With those pros, and with the decline of old school c development in enterprises (outside of .net and vc), compounded with what was said above (security, impossible to exploit buffer overflows), it’s no wonder Java is the language of choice. The main issue with Java is that it can be easily hacked clientside. Serverside… its very simple to make it bulletproof. And banks are locked down anyway so ‘hacking’ would require physical access… good luck with that.

Read full topic

item.title: Why do banks use Java?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I always assumed it was because the terminals they used ran some sort of embedded shit that was designed for java.

A lot of the point of sale frontends are Java too.

Read full topic

item.title: Why do banks use Java?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

probably because of security, in java its impossible to have a buffer overflow
in c and c++, you can attempt to store information in memory location null,
like in c, you can do this

int[] list;
list = new int[3];
list[10] = 5;

but in java if you try, you get a ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, hence, no memory is stored in a null.
iv heard that most of the last major security compromises have been because of buffer overflows,
since banks have a lot of money, its in their intrests to have a good security

im fairly sure they use java because java makes it impossible to store stuff at a null memory location

Read full topic
